title: RS20985
content: Procurement contracts used by federal agencies for various tasks in forest stewardship services involve identifying tasks to be performed, such as cutting trees and treating materials. Contracts are currently awarded to the lowest bidder, but Congress could consider other factors like local employment or bidder's past performance. There is a suggestion to collect commercially valuable material under a contract for separate sale, known as log sales, a practice common in Europe and discussed for national forests for 40 years. The current contracting methods for forest stewardship services involve identifying tasks and awarding contracts to the lowest bidder. There is a suggestion to collect commercially valuable material under a separate procurement contract for sale, known as log sales, which has been discussed for national forests for 40 years. The Forest Service has the authority for log sales but has not extensively used it. The advantages of traditional procurement contracting include simplicity, familiarity to agency personnel and contractors, and opportunities for congressional oversight. The current contracting system for forest stewardship services allows private contractors to bid on proposals, providing opportunities for congressional oversight. Traditional service procurement contracting for federal forest stewardship has limitations, including potentially high costs for treating millions of acres at risk of ecological damage from wildfires. The current contracting system for federal forest stewardship services allows private contractors to bid on proposals, providing opportunities for congressional oversight. Treating 75 million acres at high risk of ecological damage from wildfires could cost over $20 billion, with a total cost of around $70 billion for treating all 231 million federal acres. Modifications to traditional service procurement contracting could hinder efforts to improve federal forest health. Using desired conditions instead of tasks for forest stewardship could enhance stewardship efforts, but standardized measures for desired forest conditions have not been developed. To improve federal forest stewardship, using desired conditions instead of tasks is recommended, but standardized measures for desired forest conditions are lacking. Goods-for-services contracts, such as land management service contracts, stewardship contracts, and end-results contracts, offer a different approach to contracting for forest stewardship by trading commercially valuable timber for services. Pilot tests of goods-for-services contracts were authorized in the FY1992 and FY1993 Interior Appropriations Acts. Goods-for-services contracts were initially authorized in the FY1992 and FY1993 Interior Appropriations Acts, with further expansion in subsequent years. Congress established stewardship end result contracting demonstration projects, with additional projects authorized in later years. The 2002 Farm Bill considered goods-for-services stewardship contracting, with the House-passed version of H.R. 2646 authorizing such contracts for the Forest Service through FY2007. Stewardship contracting was considered in the 2002 Farm Bill, with the House and Senate versions differing on the authorization of goods-for-services contracts for the Forest Service. President Bush proposed goods-for-services stewardship contracting after the severe 2002 fire season. The final bill (P.L. 107-171) did not include a provision on goods-for-services contracting. Section 323 of the FY1999 Interior Appropriations Act was amended to authorize "stewardship end result contracting" through FY2013, extend the program to BLM lands, modify identified goals, and allow the selection of a contracting officer without constraints. The FY1999 Interior Appropriations Act amended Section 323 to authorize stewardship end result contracting through FY2013, allowing the selection of a contracting officer without constraints. Goods-for-services demonstration projects have been modified to allow non-timber harvesting requirements on purchasers, potentially increasing efficiency and lowering costs in forest stewardship activities. Goods-for-services contracting offers the advantage of greater efficiency and cost savings in forest stewardship activities by using the same equipment and personnel for both goods and services. It is seen as off-budget financing for forest stewardship, allowing federal agencies to purchase stewardship services with timber assets instead of appropriations. However, a limitation of this approach is highlighted. Goods-for-services contracting is proposed as an alternative funding mechanism for forest stewardship. However, one limitation is the higher contracting costs due to combining multiple activities in one contract. Critics suggest that simpler procedures and longer-term authorization are needed to fully realize the benefits of this approach. Critics of goods-for-services contracting suggest that longer-term authorization and simpler contracting procedures are necessary to fully benefit from this approach. There are concerns about reduced congressional oversight and control, similar to other off-budget financing mechanisms. Some question the appropriateness of exchanging goods for services, as it may incentivize managers to increase the sale of goods to provide services. Some interests have raised concerns about goods-for-services contracting, noting that exchanging goods for services can create perverse incentives for managers to increase timber sales to fund environmental restoration activities. This could exacerbate wildfire threats by bringing combustible material to ground level. Timber harvesting for forest stewardship activities may incentivize wildfire protection efforts by removing non-commercial woody biomass. However, using goods-for-services contracts primarily on lands with commercial timber could limit stewardship opportunities on other federal forests. The effectiveness of goods-for-services contracts in stewardship contracting has not been independently evaluated, despite being seen as an important experimental opportunity.
